instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2179: What is A2179? A2179 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2020 with EMC 3302, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01958..
definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.

threads.title: MacBook  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid damage, Stuck at 5v.
threads.message:
Hi Guys,

I am a new member and what a nice forum you made. Jumping on to the topic. We have a liquid damaged Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, and we need your help to fix it. We observed corrosions between <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR> chips. Cleaning with isopropyl and applying some Amtech flux to resolder. 

When the board connects to the charging cable 61W AC adapter, the USB-C amp meter shows 5v. Amper meters start with 0mA, after 1 second, 100mA and then 230mA, then back to 00 and continues. It loops. 

We have the main power rail <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.28v (should be 12.60v). But it should be 12.60. 

Checked the <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> Chips responsible for power management. Both input and LDOs are there.  

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC_X_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> - 1.5v OK
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_X_LDO</SIGNAL>      - 3.3v OK

Basically, I do not see any problems with <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> but I might be wrong. So next step is to check if the charger receives <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and it receives it (12.28v).

Then I decided to check the <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> that is signal coming from Charger (<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>) to <CHIP>U6960</CHIP>. I am using Siglent Digital Occiloscope to measure this. So I turned on the mainboard and the Siglent Occiloscope was connected to the ground and <RESISTOR>R6960</RESISTOR> (1pin). the signal is missing. Normally I should see a straight line but nothing is there. I do not know if something is preventing this signal or charger failed or maybe T2 Chip/T2 Data related issue. 

I attached the picture of the corrosion area as well. 

I am lost in the board scheme and cannot move further to troubleshoot the issue. I also referred to this link --> [URL]https://logi.wiki/index.php/CD3217_and_T2_Power_on_Sequence[/URL]

Please advise what are the next steps for troubleshooting. 

Big thanks.
Zeyd

threads.title: MacBook  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid damage, Stuck at 5v.
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Be sure all resistors in that area have correct value.
Also replace corroded caps.

Don't waste time hunting DC signal with o-scope; use DC voltmeter.
Do you get L6960 voltage?

What is the USB-C behavior (on ampmeter), when both charger and battery are connected?

threads.title: MacBook  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid damage, Stuck at 5v.
threads.message:
Thank you. I am checking the resistors at the moment.  L6960  has a 3.3v on both sides.  

I have another working exact same Macbook. I put this mainboard to the working MacBook Pro. USB-C meter shows 20.3v and 0.00 amps. It is not using any power. 

Original MacBook has burned areas and I attached pictures of it here so that you better understand the damage. I am missing also the <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> power rail on this mainboard. I do not know if this is always-on power rail or not. Please check the attached pictures.

Is it possible to test caps and make sure they are working or not?

threads.title: MacBook  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid damage, Stuck at 5v.
threads.message:
Just measured the Resistors near the corroded area without removing resistors from the board. 

<RESISTOR>R7664</RESISTOR> - 3.1 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R7666</RESISTOR> - 2.5 ohm

<RESISTOR>R7684</RESISTOR> - 2.3 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R7686</RESISTOR> - 3.2 Ohm

threads.title: MacBook  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid damage, Stuck at 5v.
threads.message:
With such damage caused by liquid on audio flex/board, T2 is very likely dead.
Leakage from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to T2 data line happens very often on these models.

threads.title: MacBook  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid damage, Stuck at 5v.
threads.message: So basically PPBUS-G3H damaged the T2 chip by shorting to the data line. Are there any other steps I can check to be sure if T2 is dead or not? Like to tell the customer the exact answer. Thank you.

threads.title: MacBook  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid damage, Stuck at 5v.
threads.message: Check diode mode to ground on T2 data lines going to audio board; like <SIGNAL>SPKRAMP_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, etc.

threads.title: MacBook  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid damage, Stuck at 5v.
threads.message: Yes, it is shorted to the ground. It made a beeping sound. This is the end, right?

threads.title: MacBook  <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> / Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid damage, Stuck at 5v.
